Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Direct-drive Modular Transverse Flux Electric Machine without Using Rare-Earth Permanent Magnet Material

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Earth Permanent Magnet Material
Abstract
The objective of this research is to develop compact, high torque density, energy-efficient, rare-earth-material-free electric machines for alternative energy and transportation applications. The approach is to use the concept of transverse flux paths with the unconventional "ring" winding that allows the increase of pole numbers without the reduction of ampere-turn per pole. The goals of this research will be achieved through electromagnetic, structural and thermal design, analysis and optimization followed by fabrication and testing of a 50kW prototype electric drive.

Intellectual Merit:
The proposed transverse flux machine has a modular structure that uses the flux focusing technique to increase air-gap flux density without having to use high flux density materials. The modularity of poles allows for easy assembly and scalability of the machine. The double windings per module or phase open the door for developing innovative control methodologies. The structure has high stator core utilization, and high fault tolerance capability, which are highly desirable features in traction machines and wind generators.

Broader Impacts:
The research will establish designs and design methodologies for high torque and power density electric machines without using expensive rare-earth magnet materials. The practical and lower cost machines to be designed will promote alternative transportation and increase the penetration rate of renewable energy harvesting technologies. The research will establish the US foothold in the area of compact, high-torque motors facilitating gearless electromechanical systems. The comprehensive educational plan built with lecture and laboratory modules on alternative energy and transportation will help train many graduate and undergraduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this research is to develop compact, high torque density, energy-efficient, rare-earth-material-free electric machines for alternative energy and transportation applications. The proposed research aimed to develop novel, modular, high torque density, direct-drive, non-rare-earth permanent magnet transverse flux (PM-TF) machines using flux-focusing techniques.  The flux focusing technique allows the use of non-rare-earth materials that will overcome the cost and availability issues of rare-earth permanent magnets. The modular structure of the proposed TF machine addresses the key assembly and service issues. 

The optimization of the transverse flux concept through electromagnetic, structural and thermal studies is achieved, and the fabrication of an electric machine and associated motor drive for experimental analysis is accomplished. Throughout the project:

  • Magnetic circuit model of the PM-TF machine is developed for the initial sizing and optimization.
  • 3-D model of the TF machine is developed using Finite Element Analysis (FEA) for improved electromagnetic performance analysis.
  • Dynamic model of the TF machine developed for control development.
  • Different winding arrangements are studied to extend flux-weakening capability of the TFM.
  • A novel concept of integrating the rotary transformer within the proposed TFM design was explored to completely eliminate the use of magnets from the TFM. The proposed TFM has a modular structure that is free of PM, which makes it cost-effective, without sacrificing its peak torque and power when compared to a similar sized PM based TFM.  
  • Different approaches for cogging torque reduction in the proposed machines were investigated. Key methods of cogging torque minimization were identified and used as design variables for optimization using a design of experiments (DOE) based on the Taguchi method. A three-level DOE is performed to reach an optimum solution with minimum simulations.
  • A new E-Core TFM architecture is proposed to reduce leakage flux and improve the power factor and the torque density of the TFMs.
  • 1 kW prototypes for both E-Core and Z-Core TFMs are built at the University of Akron.
  • Power converter to drive the TFMs is developed and tested.
  • The performance of the developed TFMs along with the control algorithms are verified through experimental results.  The prototype TFMs

Three graduate students have been engaged in research related to this project. Two Ph.D. students gained experience modeling, analysis, design, simulation, hardware development, and control of transverse flux machines. Both students have earned their degree and accepted positions as research engineers in the area of electric machine design. One MS student gained experience in mechanical noise and vibration of the TFMs. Undergraduate students were involved in building process of the TFMs. They have gained practical experience in electric machine development and testing.

Two papers in IEEE IAS Transactions are accepted for publications and nine peer-reviewed papers are published in IEEE sponsored conferences.  Four more papers are being prepared to submit to IEEE journals. One provisional patent disclosure has been filed on the E-Core TFM.

A hardware module is developed using dSPACE MicroAutoBox controller unit for system identification and parameter estimation of servo drives. The module will be used in the graduate level control of electric machines classes.
